title: Adrenoleukodystrophy: Symptoms, Causes, and Treatment
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: What Is Adrenoleukodystrophy?
content: About 1 in 17,000 people are born with a genetic disease called adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD). This severe brain disorder mainly affects boys and men. There’s no cure yet for it, but a diagnosis early in life may keep it from getting worse.

ALD causes severe damage to your nervous system. It does this by breaking apart the fatty covering (called myelin) that protects nerves in your brain and spinal cord . This makes it harder for nerves to send messages to your brain.

The adrenal glands, which help control functions such as your immune system , blood pressure, and others, are also harmed by ALD. Because of that, your body can’t make enough of the hormones you need to be healthy.

sections.heading: What Causes Adrenoleukodystrophy?
content: A mutated gene on the X chromosome (the strand of DNA that decides if you’re born male or female) is the cause of ALD. Males have one X chromosome, so only need to inherit one damaged gene from a parent to be affected. Females have two X chromosomes, so they are less likely to have ALD. If they do, it’s often less severe.

sections.heading: ALD genetic testing
content: An inherited mutation of the ABCD1 gene causes adrenoleukodystrophy. Genetic testing can identify the four types of ALD in newborns, adults, people diagnosed with Addison's disease, and family members who may not have symptoms of adrenoleukodystrophy. Since 2016, a newborn screening test for ALD has been available in several states. It detects high levels of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the blood, which confirms the presence of ALD. The screening identifies newborns at risk for cerebral ALD, which, if caught early, can be treated. You can find out whether ALD screening, also called X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy screening, is available in your state here: https://newbornscreening.hrsa.gov/your-state .

sections.heading: Types of Adrenoleukodystrophy
content: ALD can come in several different forms. Symptoms will vary with each one but often become worse over time.
Cerebral demyelinating ALD
About 45% of people with ALD have this type. It’s the most severe form of ALD. Symptoms often start between ages of 4 and 10 and include:
Adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN)

This adult form of ALD tends to have milder symptoms. About half of those who have it don’t show signs until they’re in their 20s or 30s. Still, like ALD, AMN can cause a severe loss of brain function. Some early signs are:
bullets: Problems with vision, hearing, and motor function
Viral infections that keep coming back
Skin that looks tanned or bronzed
Changes in your gait (how you walk)
Numbness or tingling in the legs
Feeling an urgent need to pee or poop
Not being able to get or keep an erection

sections.heading: How Is ALD Diagnosed?
content: The illness can take time to be diagnosed since other illnesses may need to be ruled out first. Many early symptoms can be missed or blamed on more common and milder health issues such as attention deficit disorder (ADD) or learning disabilities.

If your doctor thinks you may have adrenoleukodystrophy , they may order several tests. One is a blood test that looks for the special type of fatty acids that people with ALD have in high amounts. This test works best in men. It’s not as precise when used on women.

If your doctor thinks you may have adrenoleukodystrophy , they may order several tests. One is a blood test that looks for the special type of fatty acids that people with ALD have in high amounts. This test works best in men. It’s not as precise when used on women.

content: The other way to confirm ALD is through an MRI scan. A brain scan can look for lesions (signs of damage) caused by the disease.
Based on your results, your doctor will assign you a “Loes score.” This measures the amount of brain damage seen on a scale from 0.5 (normal) to 34. Anything above 14 is a sign of severe ALD.
Genetic testing can also show if you or your child has the ABCD1 gene mutation that causes ALD.

sections.heading: ALD Treatments
content: The list of treatments for ALD is short. They include:

Bone marrow transplant. Boys with early signs of ALD can benefit from this procedure. Healthy red blood cells from a donor can help prevent further myelin damage. The process can take months and recovery is long, but children who get a transplant early enough can have normal or near-normal lives.

Gene therapy. This new treatment takes out damaged stem cells, repairs the “faulty” gene that causes ALD, and then puts a healthy version back in. It carries fewer risks than a bone marrow transplant , but more research needs to be done before it’s widely used.

sections.heading: Steroids.
content: Your a drenal glands make hormones that control the body's blood sugar, sodium , and potassium levels. In people with Addison’s disease, the body's inability to make enough of these hormones can be life-threatening. Steroid pills help replace these hormones to manage Addison’s disease.

Physical therapy. If walking is a problem, a physical therapist can provide exercises that help strengthen your muscles and ease the painful muscle spasms and rigidity that come with ALD. Your doctor can also prescribe a wheelchair and other devices that help with mobility.

Lorenzo’s oil. This mix of rapeseed and olive oils stops the body from making certain fatty acids that cause myelin to break down. Although it may slow the onset of ALD in boys, Lorenzo’s oil isn’t yet approved by the FDA. It’s unclear whether it helps men with adrenomyeloneuropathy.

sections.heading: Prognosis for ALD
content: More research is being done on how to prevent and treat ALD, but the outlook for people who have it is still poor. Death often occurs within 1 to 10 years of having first symptoms. The earlier ALD can be diagnosed, the better. Experts believe that all treatments work best when given before symptoms start or soon after.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Adrenoleukodystrophy (ADL) is a genetic condition in which your body is unable to break down a type of fatty acid called VLCFAs, which build up in the brain, nervous system, and adrenal glands. The most common type of ADL, X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, comes from a mutation on the X chromosome. It affects boys and men most severely. While there's no cure for a drenoleukodystrophy, early detection and treatment, especially in newborns, can slow the progression of the disease and ease symptoms.

sections.heading: Adrenoleukodystrophy FAQs
content: What is the life expectancy of someone with ALD?

Life expectancy for ALD depends on the severity of symptoms and the type you have. The form of ALD with the poorest prognosis is cerebral ALD (CALD), for which symptoms begin to appear around the ages of 4 to 10 and progress rapidly. Adult onset symptoms of ALD are milder than those of CALD, with 28 being the average age at which symptoms start to appear. Patients with ALD who don't have brain involvement (the disease hasn't affected their brain) have a better prognosis than those who do.

sections.heading: Can a child recover from ALD?
content: Adrenoleukodystrophy has no cure, but there are promising treatments involving gene therapy and stem cell therapy that slow the progression of the disease if symptoms are caught early.
How rare is ALD disease?
Adrenoleukodystrophy is a rare genetic disease linked to the X chromosome that mainly affects those who are born male. However, ADL occurs worldwide in all races, ethnicities, and nationalities.
